Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assessing the Impact of Arctic Sea Ice Variability on the Greenland Ice Sheet Surface Mass and Energy Balance
Award.AbstractNarration: The Arctic Ocean is rapidly losing its summer sea ice cover, leading to anomalous warming of the overlying atmosphere in autumn. Concurrent with this sea ice loss, the Greenland ice sheet has been losing mass recently, with increased surface melt and discharge rates. These changes are of great socioeconomic concern as continued negative trends in the extent of floating sea ice cover and ice sheet mass are likely to have widespread impacts on climate and global sea levels. The investigators propose that the simultaneous decreases in sea ice cover and increased melting of the Greenland ice sheet are connected. On the one hand, both may be largely responding to the same forcing to some degree, such as a generalized warming signal, amplified over the Arctic. On the other hand, it can be hypothesized that sea ice variability, through influences on mixed ocean layer temperatures, overlying air temperatures, column water vapor and atmospheric circulation, influences Greenland ice sheet surface melt and accumulation. Through a combination of data analysis, process studies and modeling, this project seeks to define the interactions between sea ice loss and Greenland ice sheet melt and accumulation. The following major research questions provide a framework for the study: 1) Does sea ice variability influence Greenland ice sheet surface melt (where, when, and how)? 2) What is the nature of storm activity around Greenland in the context of ice and ocean conditions and how might changes in the marine environment influence Greenland surface melt and accumulation in the future? This investigation will take advantage of up-to-date satellite sensor data, in combination with several new atmospheric reanalysis data products, station data and a state-of-the-art regional climate model, performed by a research team who are specialists in regional climate modeling, analysis of geospatial and sequential data analysis, satellite remote sensing and hydroclimatology in the Arctic and Greenland. This project will support students at the University of Colorado, the City College of New York and Rutgers University. The project also includes efforts to recruit undergraduates from underrepresented groups and will support a New Jersey high school teacher to develop lecture plans to be disseminated to a wide audience of K-12 educators at conferences and in journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project in object aimed at understading the potential linkages between the disapperance of sea ice and melting over the Greenland ice sheet. The influence of sea ice on Greenland melting can occur at local scale through the local warming induced by the removal of the bright sea ice surface with the dark, warmer ocean and through the impact of sea ice on atmospehric circulation. We used remote sensing, modeled outputs and in-situ observations to tackle the problem. 

A paper was published in 2016 by a PhD student funded under this project (Mioduszewski et al., 2016) which demonstrated that positive anomalies in Greenland melt are associated with atmospheric circulation anomalies. The study used artificial neural networks (e.g., artificial intelligence) to study the problem and quantified that 75% of Greenland melt anomalies are a result of Arctic warming, 17% to dynamics (circulation pattern frequency) and 8% to dynamics acting on thermodynamics. Our team further found positive height anomalies near Greenland are associated with positive height anomalies over the Beaufort Sea, a pattern which also promotes summer ice loss, resulting in strong co-variability between Greenland melt and Beaufort Sea ice in early summer. A possible local influence was also found between sea ice in Baffin Bay and Greenland melt. This is the only region where a local-scale influence was observed.

A second paper was published on the Cryosphere, entitled Investigating the Local Scale Influence of Sea Ice on Greenland Surface Melt (Stroeve et al., 2017). The paper has been published in 2017. In the study we investigated the relationship between sea ice concentration, the timing of melt onset and open water fraction surrounding Greenland with ice sheet surface melt using a combination of remote sensing observations, and outputs from a reanalysis model and a regional climate model for the period 1979–2015. Our results point to covariability between Greenland ice sheet surface melt and sea ice within Baffin Bay and Davis Strait. While some of this covariance can be explained by simultaneous influence of atmospheric circulation anomalies on both the sea ice cover and Greenland melt, within Baffin Bay we find a modest correlation between detrended melt onset over sea ice and the adjacent ice sheet melt onset. This correlation appears to be related to increased transfer of sensible and latent heat fluxes from the ocean to the atmosphere in early sea ice melt years, increasing temperatures and humidity over the ice sheet that in turn initiate ice sheet melt.

 

Lastly, our team approached the problem of understanding the impact of  anti-cyclonic/cyclonic conditions on Greenland SMB. A paper is currently ready for submission to Nature climate Change. Since 2002, when gravimetric measurements from space are available, the Greenland ice sheet (GrIS) has been losing mass at a rate of ~ 270 Gt a-1. We find that atmospheric patterns played a crucial role in the acceleration of mass loss between 2002 and 2012 and the following reduction in mass loss rate starting in 2013, through the modulation of runoff and snowfall. We also found that atmospheric conditions driving the extreme surface and total mass losses observed during the first part of the GRACE period are cosnistent with sea ice losses  and are likely unique since a least the 1850s, extending our analysis back to the pre-satellite and pre-reanalysis era.
